description: {"blocks":[{"key":"f1rgn","text":"Dissolved black carbon (DBC) is the condensed aromatic portion of dissolved organic matter produced from the incomplete combustion of biomass and other thermogenic processes. DBC quantification facilitates the examination of the production, accumulation, cycling, transformation, and effects of biologically recalcitrant condensed aromatic carbon in aquatic environments. Due to the heterogeneous nature of DBC molecules, concentrations are difficult to measure directly. Here, the method for DBC quantification consists of oxidizing condensed aromatic carbon to benzenepolycarboxylic acids (BPCAs), which are used as proxies for the assessment of DBC in the original sample. The concentrations of BPCA oxidation products are quantified using high-performance liquid chromatography. DBC concentrations are determined from the concentration of BPCAs using a previously established conversion factor. Details and full descriptions of the preparative and analytical procedures and techniques of the BPCA method are usually omitted for brevity in published method sections and method-specific papers. With this step-by-step protocol, we aim to clarify the steps of DBC analysis, especially for those adopting or conducting the BPCA method for the first time. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"f8974","text":"A helpful spreadsheet detailing necessary calculations is included here and utilized multiple times throughout the protocol:   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":126}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":125,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6nl1d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adgr9","text":"Expected Protocol Timeline: From start to finish, completion of this protocol for dissolved black carbon (DBC) analysis will take approximately one week. However, there are multiple points in the protocol where the preparative procedures can be paused and resumed at a later time. Before starting each step in the procedure, read ahead to make sure you have allocated sufficient time to complete each step before reaching a designated pause point. To achieve maximum sample preparation efficiency and data consistency, we recommend that samples are prepared in relevant batches, rather than one at a time. For example, solid phase extracted dissolved organic carbon (DOC) can be archived in the freezer until an entire sample set is collected, then the samples can be analyzed for DBC in one batch.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4v2sr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tmrc","text":"Chemical steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Prepare and condition cartridges
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9gr9h","text":"The solid phase extraction (SPE) cartridges used in this protocol (Agilent Bond Elut PPL cartridge, 1g, 6 mL) is packed with a styrene-divinylbenzene polymer resin that recovers high proportions of dissolved organic matter (DOM) on a per-carbon basis. It is important that the headspace is nearly filled with pH 2 water to ensure the cartridge remains conditioned and will not dry out before DOM extraction.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Prepare and condition cartridges
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"42ds0","text":"Store SPE cartridges in the refrigerator at    until DOM extraction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":44,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cgm7i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ck3ld","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52smh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"8D76CEA08ED311EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":39,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2hujo","text":"Do not store cartridges in the freezer as water expansion will cause the caps to come off and resin to dry out.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ff0t8","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2tsb3","text":"Conditioned SPE cartridges may be stored like this in the refrigerator for several weeks to months. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b47hj","text":"At this point, the water sample should have been filtered and analyzed for dissolved organic carbon (DOC) concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9e8kv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d16vc","text":"Acidify the filtered water sample to pH 2 using hydrochloric acid.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c2t9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ed5qq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17g3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fdkdc","text":"Adding 2 mL of 6 N hydrochloric acid (or 1 mL of 12 N hydrochloric acid) to 1 L of filtered sample water usually brings the pH value close to 2. However, depending on sample composition and buffering capacities, additional hydrochloric acid may be needed to sufficiently reduce the pH.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9ea4f","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"anunk","text":"After each hydrochloric acid addition, cap and vigorously mix the sample, then test the pH by dropping the solution onto a pH strip or by using a pH meter.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"29gp1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":52,"offset":129,"style":"bold"}],"key":"d9utp","text":"The acidification of the sample protonates molecules contained within DOM so they effectively sorb to the conditioned SPE resin. The acidification step is critical for DOM recovery.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3rnr1","text":"Set up SPE apparatus and begin flow of acidified sample through SPE cartridge.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"daang","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jeuc","text":"   ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7kcfu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B6679D906F0B11ECA6296F943B28F2BB","height":733,"id":209573,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6rg9d","text":"Image of SPE apparatus for 5 samples. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"SPE.jpeg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxhbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxfbj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxgbj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxebj36p.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8nt5c","text":"Open each stopcock sequentially, checking to make sure sample is flowing to and effluent is flowing from each cartridge and that flow is exiting the manifold. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5p1ed","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kc52","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fag1o","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c8jl7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4qdk2","text":"You can also double check for sample acidification by letting the effluent drip onto pH paper.  ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eqrrr","text":"Place an appropriately sized container beneath the manifold to capture SPE effluent and wait until extraction is complete (i.e. the entire sample volume has passed through the SPE cartridge by gravity).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clovo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9iti7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"60m48","text":"Depending upon sample volume, sample composition and/or flow rate, this extraction step can take anywhere from a few hours to a full day to complete. It is typical to set up extractions in the afternoon, then leave the extraction to continue overnight and complete the following steps the following day. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"80vpo","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":34,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"59uep","text":"Possible issues during extraction:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4ritq","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6891d","text":"Small sample bottles - It may be necessary to secure the sample bottles on the shelf, as they may be displaced by the weight of the tubes after sample is drained from the bottle. This is typically a problem for smaller bottle sizes (e.g., less than 1 L) and should be considered during extraction setup.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4kpoa","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2sqit","text":"Bubbles in headspace - Formation of bubbles can introduce air to the resin and slow the flow rate of sample. If small bubbles form in the SPE cartridge headspace, gently tap the side of the cartridge with a pen or similar object. If you observe the formation of large bubbles or major gaps of air in the headspace, remove adapter cap connection and allow sample to flow and refill headspace of cartridge, then reattach adapter. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5i36k","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":19,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"401h","text":"Flocculation of DOM - If there are no bubbles present and flow through SPE cartridge is slow, check to see if the white filter (above resin) has turned brown and/or accumulated sample particulates. In highly concentrated samples (e.g., samples collected from a wetland or during peak river discharge), DOM may flocculate out of solution when acidified to pH 2 and clog the SPE cartridge. If flow is slow, but still dripping, leave samples to extract overnight or for 24 hours. If flow has stopped completely or is prohibitively slow, then you may use another SPE cartridge to extract DOM from the remaining volume. Depending upon sample DOC concentration and expected SPE recovery, the volume of sample extracted prior to clogging may be sufficient for further analyses.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3gtbe","text":"Rinse SPE cartridges with pH 2 water (3 headspace volumes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1u3cl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8n54j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"feaab","text":"At this point, the SPE cartridges have sample DOM sorbed to the resin. This step desalts the sample by rinsing off potentially interfering inorganic material that may be stuck to the resin.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7rmlc","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3kef3","text":"For this step, the pH 2 water should be made fresh by adding 2 mL of 6 N hydrochloric acid (or 1 mL of 12 N hydrochloric acid) to 1 L of ultrapure water. To avoid contamination by organic material, it is important to use pre-cleaned glassware and to make up the pH 2 water solution just before use.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"s3r7","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7m27f","text":"Transfer pH 2 water to cartridge with a volumetric pipette. Allow pH 2 water to flow through the cartridge until the meniscus is almost touching the white filter located above the resin. Repeat two more times.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"97ngu","text":"Record the mass of the empty sample bottle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkcs4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bpei","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2mb4j","text":"Recording this mass is necessary for determining the actual volume of sample extracted.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3ivdg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bli78","text":"Note that there will likely be some sample remaining in the sample bottle.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"62iac","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"78kam","text":"If you do not have access to an appropriate balance, then the volume of sample extracted can also be determined by measuring the volume of SPE effluent using a graduated cylinder.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7vqfn","text":"At this point, you may continue directly on to the next step or recap DOM-containing SPE cartridges and wrap in aluminum foil and freeze/refrigerate until continuing on to the next step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

sure manifold valves are set so that gas will flow freely through every SPE cartridge and no gas flow escapes through other manifold openings.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ccgsr","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d140t","text":"We ZY-96410-16)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f2l3i","text":"connectors: Male luer to male luer (Masterflex HV-30800-14), male luer ZY-45501-02)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1n18s","text":"adapters: Five port manifold with female luer locks (Masterflex 12131001)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"46kk1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"57pml","text":"However, other materials and configurations may be used to construct a drying apparatus that works best for your lab setup.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7jn0","text":"Turn on gas flow.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9ib7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dj6ve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2mlgg","text":"Keep gas flow relatively high at first, until water stops spitting rapidly from the SPE cartridges.  Then reduce flow to a point where you can just feel it on the back of your hand when held near the outflow of the SPE cartridge. Here, you want to find a balance that minimizes both drying time and gas waste. This will take some trial and error to determine the appropriate flow rate for your specific drying setup.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c2hun","text":"Allow gas to flow until SPE cartridge resin is completely dry.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b7a78","text":"    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"565na","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1u1io","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29lb2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8et9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2obk5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvr9g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"BC20C1508E9411EC8207930DE5B60B3E","height":412,"id":209581,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4hpc","text":"Image of SPE cartridges with partially-dry resin.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"IMG_0249.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxrbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxpbj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxqbj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxnbj36p.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bptv6","text":"Dry resin has a lighter color and feels room temperature to the touch when gas is flowing through columns. If you are unsure whether the resin is dry, unhook and tap the side of the cartridge – The resin is dry when it moves freely, like dry sand, in the cartridge.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ejspu","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"10cdh","text":"Since the resin swells slightly when wet, you may observe extra space in the resin area (between the two white filters) after extraction and drying - This is normal and will not affect the next extraction steps.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"12h79","text":"Turn off gas at the tank and remove dry SPE cartridges from manifolds. Repeat drying process as necessary to dry the rest of the SPE cartridges in the sample set.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b56ra","text":"Remember to turn off gas when you are done. If you do not have time to move on to the next step, cap the SPE cartridges and wrap in aluminum foil until you are ready to elute the DOM. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c5sot","text":"Label glass vials with sample identifier or name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21c4d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a9vp0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"153qu","text":"Here, we typically use 12 mL glass vials with Teflon-lined caps. The 12 mL volume minimizes vial headspace and takes up less freezer space if a large number of samples are being collected and archived.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"munb","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dre7s","text":"We suggest typing or writing sample identifiers on paper and then using clear tape to fix labels to vials. Spilled methanol or solvent fumes will dissolve permanent marker and distort certain adhesive labels.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"afrpj","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9s8mp","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f7mca","text":"Record the mass of the empty glass vial (with cap on).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15krn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9apep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dem1v","text":"Recording this mass is necessary for determining the actual volume of methanol used to elute DOM from the SPE cartridge.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2buii","text":"Using a test tube rack, or similar apparatus, suspend the SPE cartridges in preparation for DOM elution. Remove caps from vials and place them underneath their corresponding SPE cartridges.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6k5v","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"65j43","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7pml2","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cqh59","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":52,"offset":304,"style":"bold"}],"key":"djd6c","text":"This setup is meant to facilitate elution of DOM in methanol from the SPE cartridge directly into the glass vial to ensure no DOM is lost during transfer. The outlet tips of the SPE cartridges should hover just above the opening of the glass vials to ensure that no drips of sample eluate miss the vial. It is essential that you collect the first few drops when eluting DOM with methanol, as these first drops are the most concentrated with DOM.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"58m3","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"45j4o","text":"Keep vial caps organized so the correct cap can be placed on the corresponding vial after elution. This is necessary to ensure accurate quantification of methanol volumes since caps vary slightly in their measured mass.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"7AB844B06F0C11ECA6296F943B28F2BB","height":412,"id":209585,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4p4kv","text":"Image of elution apparatus with samples mid-elution. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Elution2.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxvbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxtbj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxubj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnxsbj36p.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6tcp0","text":"In this step, DOM is eluted from the SPE resin with methanol and collected directly in a glass vial. It is important to use analytical grade methanol so as not to contaminate the DOM sample with extraneous material.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":101,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3dm0b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jvd1","text":"Elute DOM from the SPE resin by adding 3 x 3 mL aliquots of methanol to the cartridge.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41ave","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1i2cu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as9ad","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3u1om","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1eh73","text":"Fill beaker with methanol, then transfer ~3 mL of methanol from beaker to cartridge with a volumetric pipette. Allow methanol to flow through the cartridge until the meniscus is almost touching the white filter located above the resin. Repeat two more times, letting the final 3 mL aliquot of methanol drain completely from the cartridge into the vial.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7jsj4","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"19ee5","text":"The total volume of methanol used to elute DOM from the SPE cartridges described here (Agilent Bond Elut PPL cartridge, 1g, 6 mL) is ~9 mL, but this volume may be adjusted to accommodate different resin masses and/or cartridge headspaces.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fansq","text":"Once flow from the SPE cartridges has stopped, close each vial with their corresponding cap.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9r443","text":"Record the mass of the eluate-filled glass vial (with cap on).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5vnq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6g4c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ab6p","text":"Recording this mass is necessary for determining the actual volume of methanol used to elute DOM from the SPE cartridge.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Transfer of SPE-DOC eluate to ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"rem5","text":"Using the spreadsheet linked below (PPL tab), calculate the volume of DOM eluate that should be dried down for DBC analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gur1","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"84d4p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ub3s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jqgh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0ufl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"de1s5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3smsq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esuqg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bvrki","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"db81f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a4vb6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"2801F7E08EC211EC8207930DE5B60B3E","id":209210,"original_name":"Example PPL-BPCA Calculations.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnj4bj36p.xlsx"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":96,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7gsf4","text":"For robust DBC analysis, we recommend oxidizing ~0.5 mg of solid phase extracted DOC (SPE-DOC). By entering the following values into the spreadsheet, you will calculate the volume of sample passed through the SPE cartridge, the volume of methanol eluate recovered from the SPE cartridge, and the volume of DOM-containing methanol eluate that needs to be dried down for sample oxidation and analysis:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dmqsh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"h8q9","text":"Sample DOC concentration (μM)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"og85","text":"Mass of full sample bottle (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bm6v6","text":"Mass of empty sample bottle (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8urdl","text":"Mass of empty glass vial (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"14vsg","text":"Mass of full glass vial (g)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ats0a","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jul9","text":"Example calculations are included in the spreadsheet.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1te92","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3arb4","text":"Assumptions made - The calculations used here assume 60% recovery of bulk DOC from river and other freshwater samples and 45% recovery from coastal marine and open ocean samples during solid phase extraction (Dittmar et al., 2008). The percent recovery of SPE-DOC should be adjusted according to the type of water sample being extracted. If you are unsure of what the SPE-DOC recovery is for a specific sample type, you may want to measure it directly. Otherwise, we suggest 50% as a good starting point until you become more familiar with the sample composition.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3gbpg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":40,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2bmpt","text":"What if I have less than 0.5 mg SPE-DOC? Smaller amounts of SPE-DOC may be used for DBC analysis, but this is highly dependent upon the amount and quality of DBC that is expected for a given sample based upon preliminary data or known biogeochemical factors. See Wagner et al. (2017) and the main manuscript text for further discussion on this. When working with a new or biogeochemically unknown sample set, we strongly recommend starting with 0.5 mg SPE-DOC until you become more familiar with the limitations of your analytical setup and sample DBC composition.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Dittmar T, Koch B, Hertkorn N, Kattner G.","can_edit":1,"date":"1213149600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.4319/lom.2008.6.230","guid":"9E3188608ED411EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":1560,"journal":"Limnol. Oceanogr.: Meth","protocol_id":null,"title":"A simple and efficient method for the solid-phase extraction of dissolved organic matter (SPE-DOM) from seawater"}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Wagner S, Brandes J, Goranov AI, Drake TW, Spencer RGM, Stubbins A.","can_edit":1,"date":1514764800,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1002/lom3.10219","guid":"42CE8250604611EC9D0237810C532F64","id":1463,"journal":"Limnol. Oceanogr.: Meth","protocol_id":null,"title":"Online quantification and compound-specific stable isotopic analysis of black carbon in environmental matrices via liquid chromatography-isotope ratio mass spectrometry"}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"ecfp7","text":"Transfer to ampules:  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dorlo","text":"·         Micropipette and glass Pasteur pipette (precombusted and connected to pipette via tubing), methanol, waste beaker, DOM eluate vials from Step 3, 2-mL ampules  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eash7","text":"·         Triple-rinse glass pipette with methanol (always do this between samples as well to prevent carryover)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2avfh","text":"·         Using the volume of methanol eluate to dry value from calculations (V MeOH to dry from BPCA prep example spreadsheet), transfer eluate to ampule with the correct Sample ID","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"frp0e","text":"o   When transferring the methanol extract, insert tip of Pasteur pipette into methanol extract and gently pump up and down 3-5 times until headspace in the Pasteur pipette is equilibrated and bubbles no longer form during pumping in the sample. After a few pumps (and no bubbles forming), draw in the target amount of methanol extract and transfer to the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"79a0n","text":"o   Put pipette tip all the way down the neck of the ampule and try to make sure the solution goes directly to the bottom of the ampule (not the sides and especially not the neck)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"djl14","text":"·         Triple rinse pipette with methanol; dispose each washing in waste beaker","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"cgf9r","text":"·         Repeat for each sample   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"ahvlc","text":"Dry ampules  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2dh61","text":"·         Drying oven, ampules with DOM eluate, Kimwipe, container to hold ampules  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eim75","text":"·         Place ampules in drying oven (lightly place a Kimwipe over them to keep dust, liquid, etc. from dropping in the ampule and contaminating the sample)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"19c3f","text":"·         Make sure to dry to completion (at least overnight and maybe a second night to be safe if you are unsure if it is fully dry) as the reaction between nitric acid and undried methanol is explosive … and you will lose sample.  Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"4j9p1","text":"o   See if any has creeped up the sides during evaporation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8m9tp","text":"o   Note any vials that have eluate in the neck so you can pay special interest in them later   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ffr5p","text":"Add nitric acid to ampules (do not start unless you can do Step 8-9 right after!)  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4ne4u","text":"·         Concentrated nitric acid, micropipette with glass or plastic tip, dried DOM eluate in ampules  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3v21o","text":"·         Once the methanol is evaporated from the ampules, in a fume hood, add 500uL of nitric acid to each ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"33sus","text":"o   Check notes and visually examine the ampules to see if there is any DOM in the neck.  Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"crm5s","text":"o   If there is any visible DOC in the neck, attempt to rinse it down with the nitric. If this is not done the DOC can char during the sealing of the ampule, potentially producing a BPCA artifact during subsequent analyses","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cn7cc","text":"o   Do not start this step if you do not have the time to immediately seal them, wait until you can because the reaction starts once you add the nitric acid   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"85lsd","text":"Seal the ampules  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"71j7n","text":"·             Blow torch, long tweezers, safety goggles, beaker of water     Method (see image above):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"52kg0","text":"·         Turn on torch","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fr0ko","text":"·         Hold ampule at a 45 degree angle. Use your hand for the base and long, metal tweezers for the top","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"94cd4","text":"·         Roll the upper neck of the ampule in the flame until the glass is malleable","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6756n","text":"·         Gently stretch the glass by pulling the tweezers farther from the flame until it is separated from the rest of the ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e5es0","text":"·         Drop the glass top from the tweezers into a beaker of water","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9h1nn","text":"·         Examine the ampule:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"cpuqc","text":"o   There should be no holes and the end should resemble a candle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8sd9k","text":"·         Repeat with all samples  Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fse2d","text":"o   If you are new to sealing columns, practice with empty ampules. Wait until you are confident with the technique before working with real samples. This will prevent sample loss due to incorrect sealing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"51pe5","text":"o   You don’t want to twist the glass too much as the seal won’t be as good. Spinning back and forth with the fingers holding the bottom of the ampule and gently clicking the tweezers to allow the top of the ampule to also spin but keep it from flopping when the glass gets malleable.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b2ero","text":"o   Leave the tip of the sealed ampule in the flame as you place the top end in the beaker of water. This ensures a rounder top and better seal","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bpehg","text":"o   If there is a hole, reseal using the same method described above. It is easier to reseal if your original seal is farther from the neck","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6rljs","text":"o   Do not pick up the ampule by the top right after sealing (I know it’s obvious that it is hot, but you will definitely end up doing it and it will hurt)   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"6crdg","text":"Oxidize  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fh4da","text":"·         Sealed ampules, tin foil, glass beaker (to hold ampules), programmable oven (we typically use an old GC oven)  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7jomi","text":"·         Place three ampules in tinfoil pouches (particularly useful if you are analyzing replicates; if one ampule explodes you won’t mess up the labels on the rest of them)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bddc7","text":"·         Place pouches together in a beaker (to keep them from rolling around) and place in the oven","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6g3ic","text":"·         Set oven to ramp up from 25 degrees C to 160 degrees C with a ramp of 5 degrees per minute","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dhf50","text":"·         The oven should be set to stay at 160 degrees for 360 minutes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b7ced","text":"·         Allow samples to cool to room temperature before storing them in the freezer or for continuing with the next steps     Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6hnjh","text":"o   You must be around when it finishes to put in the freezer. Plan accordingly because there’s 6-7 hours from when you put them in the oven to when you need to put them in the freezer   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"62g25","text":"Evaporating the nitric acid      Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"67ajh","text":"·         Sandbath, hot plate, needles, tubing, ring stands  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"953b3","text":"·         Set up drying apparatus (see image above)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c4qpd","text":"o   Turn on hot plates and allow sand to heat up (1 hr); hot plates should be set such that the sand bath reaches a temperature of ~60*C – The exact knob settings will need to be optimized for your specific hotplate","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a58qm","text":"o       Only prepare samples that you can dry that day (in photos you can do 10 at a time and it takes approx. 1 hr for the samples to dry)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"a647k","text":"o   Will also need a glass and plastic waste container","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9p8k","text":"o   Crack off top of the ampules (SAVE THE TOP, see image below)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dd1s3","text":"§  Hold bottom upright in one hand and, with your other hand,  place your thumb under the bulb and your pointer finger on the opposite side up the neck","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1f6us","text":"§  Crack open away from you – If you are having trouble opening the ampules, ampule opening devices are available for purchase","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"a4ane","text":"·         Rinse the ampule tops","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"3e4dk","text":"o   Pipette 40uL of nitric acid into the tops of each ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f3ulb","text":"o   Roll \u0026 swirl top of ampule to rinse the entire inner surface area to dissolve any BPCAs that may be stuck in the top of the ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"486e","text":"o   Using a fresh pipette tip (change after each sample), transfer the nitric from the top of the ampule to the corresponding bottom (where the rest of the sample is)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"a5mt6","text":"·             Evaporate the nitric acid in the ampule bottoms","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b65gg","text":"o   Push ampule into sand, just below the shoulder (5 per sand bath, it is easier to start with the centermost position)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"pr8e","text":"o   Remove needle covers and clean each needle with methanol on a Kimwipe","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bldu8","text":"o   Insert needle into the headspace of the ampule (as low as you can without submerging)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"f39fu","text":"o   Open N2 or Ar tank","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"c64se","text":"§  Slowly turn up the N­2 or Ar flow","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"7qi02","text":"§  Should make the liquid shimmer (not bubble up)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9ukpa","text":"§  You should see fumes comping from the ampules","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ftdek","text":"§  Feel free to adjust flow or needle height periodically as the liquid level decreases to optimize evaporation; this step requires a watchful eye and some degree of “babysitting” and adjusting to ensure efficient evaporation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6oq94","text":"·         Allow to dry completely (~1hr if monitored/adjusted as described above)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"l2l0","text":"o   There should be absolutely know condensation on the ampule or needle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"aep3v","text":"o   Turn off flow of N2 or Ar","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8ik9n","text":"o   Carefully remove needles from the ampules","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6r705","text":"o   Remove ampules from the sand bath – If at this point, it is obvious that not all acid has dried, the ampules must go back in the sandbath for further drying","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"2v35r","text":"o   Wipe needles with methanol and a Kimwipe","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7j35k","text":"§  Either replace the needle covers or repeat drying procedure with more samples  Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"86ugd","text":"o   Be careful when inserting and removing needles: you could poke yourself or accidentally get sand on your samples!","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dacuv","text":"o   If sand does get into the ampules, don’t panic – Take notes on which samples were affected and check chromatograms later for possible contamination.   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9qdr2","text":"Transferring from ampule to HPLC vial  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"734qd","text":"·         Pipette, glass waste container, Buffer A, 2-mL HPLC vials, 300-uL glass inserts for HPLC vials  Method:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2smdu","text":"·         Fill labeled HPLC vials with 300uL inserts – Inserts may not be necessary if large amounts of OC were oxidized initially (\u003e\u003e\u003e 0.5 mg-OC), but this is uncommon for field-collected DOC samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1o5fh","text":"·         Pipette target volume of Buffer A (Wagner et al. 2017) into dried ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3cddd","text":"o   Normally adding 200uL for 0.5mg of C but could go down to 150uL or up to 250uL depending on the expected BPCA concentration of your samples – These adjustments will become more obvious as you run more samples and understand environmental BPCA trends and expected ratios of BC:OC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"doq3l","text":"o   Be sure to record the volume of Buffer A you use to transfer as this is important for calculating the concentrations of BPCAs (see V mobile in attached BPCA prep example spreadsheet)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ccfl8","text":"·         Shake/swirl/run along every inner surface area of the ampule","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"dj7uv","text":"o   However you do this, be consistent between samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eoi8q","text":"o   Example: shake/shimmy the ampule for a while, then tilt the ampule bottom up and down to get the sides (rotating after going up-down side to dissolve any BPCAs on a different portion of the side of the ampule). Repeat these steps multiple times.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9b9l0","text":"·         Using fresh glass or plastic pipette tips for each sample, transfer the liquid from the ampule to the HPLC vial with insert","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"hj1b","text":"o   Make sure to put the tip of the pipette all the way down into the insert to keep an air bubble from forming. If this bubble forms capping the vial and gently shaking should dislodge it","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"eiq2o","text":"·         Cap the vials","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d34qo","text":"o   Now the sample is ready to analyze using HPLC or ready to be frozen until then!           Running BPCAs on HPLC  Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9thu8","text":"·         HPLC vials, samples in labeled HPLC vials, HPLC w/Chromeleon software, o-phosphoric acid, NaH2PO4 monohydrate, Na2HPO4 heptahydrate, two 1L volumetric flasks, BPCA standards (benzenehexacarboxylic acid (B6CA), benzenepentacarboxylic acid (B5CA), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (B4CA), 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylic acid 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (B3CAs))","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"buh73","text":"Prepare HPLC Buffers:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4bb6r","text":"·         Make sure there are fresh buffer solutions (if not make some)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"623gq","text":"o   Buffer A: 40 mL of o-phosphoric acid in 1L of MilliQ water (use volumetric flask)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8is9i","text":"o   Buffer B: 2.42 g of NaH2PO4 monohydrate \u0026 0.64 g of Na2HPO4 heptahydrate in 1L of MilliQ water","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fohcr","text":"·         Put ~1.5 mL of the Buffer A solution into a HPLC vial labeled “Blank” and cap","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"62kgn","text":"Prepare BPCA standards and MilliQ:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"12a5k","text":"·         Make a 5000 uM-C BPCA standard stock solution in a 100 mL volumetric flask with each BPCA standard","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"656m9","text":"o   Weigh out BPCA Standards:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eaur","text":"§  Make sure to record actual mass of each BPCA weighed out as this actual value is what will be used for calculations (see calibration tab in BPCA example spreadsheet).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"b9gro","text":"§  Example Table:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"24f52","text":"1,2,4-B3CA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3nq4p","text":"1,2,4,5-B4CA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"30um1","text":"12.700","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"et07h","text":"12.749","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"dm1bn","text":"B5CA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"234a1","text":"13.560","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"d3amr","text":"13.618","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"agbi","text":"B6CA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"af2dr","text":"14.260","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eurnh","text":"o   Put all of the standards into a 100 mL volumetric flask","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"er2ik","text":"o   Dissolve standards in Buffer A","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bl6s5","text":"§  If necessary, submerge flask in warm sonicator to help facilitate dissolution","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"djgui","text":"o   These standards are made based on concentration of Carbon. The concentrations of each BPCA will be calculated later on (see Calibration Tab of BPCA example spreadsheet).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"cip6o","text":"Notes:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"mjd4","text":"o   All BPCAs are included in the standard solution but not all of them are measured for dissolved black carbon concentrations. Please see Wagner et al. (2017) and Stubbins et al. (2015) supporting information for further details and justification","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"c3pgk","text":"o   Weighing tips:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"45kul","text":"§  Cut weigh paper into a small square and fold in half diagonally (this makes it easier to pour into the volumetric flask later)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"4nngj","text":"§  Use a microbalance","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3f8o9","text":"·         Dilute Stock solution to make 2000, 1000, 500, 200, 100, 50, 25 uM standards","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2ru61","text":"o   We usually make dilutions using 10mL volumetric flasks and dilute with mobile phase A each time","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a1foo","text":"o   Consider transferring standard dilutions from 10mL volumetric flasks into glass vials for longer term storage and easy access when running them during analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6gg0n","text":"·         Put ~1 mL of each standard solution (including the stock 5000uM-C) into a labeled HPLC vial and cap","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4chpj","text":"·         Put ~1.5 mL of MilliQ water into a HPLC vial labeled “MilliQ” and cap","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Transfer of SPE-DOC eluate to ampules

Paper or adhesive labels may burn or be removed in the oxidation oven.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Evaporation of methanol from SPE-DOC eluate
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"786qh","text":"In this step methanol is evaporated completely from the eluate to obtain the dry SPE-DOC residue for oxidation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4t7f7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a73jn","text":"Place ampules in a properly vented drying oven set to   . Loosely place a Kimwipe over the ampule openings to prevent contamination from extraneous material during drying. Depending upon the eluate volume, methanol evaporation can take anywhere from 12 to 36 hours. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":54,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9sg6u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eouqm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9uge0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1iij","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9soo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"96D0E9408ED311EC802EFB706FB7ACDA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"60","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":170,"offset":131,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ak3po","text":"If you are unsure whether methanol is completely evaporated, then place the ampules back in the oven and dry for a few more hours. The reaction between concentrated nitric acid and excess methanol is explosive, therefore complete evaporation of methanol before moving on to the next step is essential.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5cu3u","text":"Do not begin this step if you do not have the time to flame-seal ampules and perform sample oxidation immediately thereafter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":125}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aokh9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73kgo","text":"Using a volumetric, mechanical pipette, add 0.5 mL of analytical grade nitric acid (15.8N) to each ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7d2f4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"u819","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bm4n5","text":"During nitric acid addition, visually examine the ampules to determine whether there is any SPE-DOC residue in the ampule neck. If there is any visible SPE-DOC in the neck (methanol eluate can creep up the sides of the ampule during drying and deposit SPE-DOC), rinse it down with nitric acid.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3slij","text":"Flame seal the glass ampules.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ees0p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"17nnj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":101,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"73vmr","text":"If you are new to sealing glass ampules with an open flame torch, practice first with empty ampules. Do not attempt to seal ampules containing critical samples until you are comfortable and confident with the flame sealing technique. Inadequate sealing of samples will result in sample loss during oxidation.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1a07b","text":"Examine the ampule for a proper seal and repeat the previous step for each ampule in the sample set.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46g82","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbo8t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8k9ck","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6l671","text":"The sealed end of the ampule should resemble a candle flame. If you notice any holes in the seal, you may attempt to reseal using the same method described above. Note that it is more difficult to seal an ampule on the second try because the neck area is considerably shorter. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Oxidation of SPE-DOC with nitric acid
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cngpp","text":"Wrap ampules in aluminum foil pouches, usually 3 to 5 ampules per pouch.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c66n3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7sjmv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dnbuk","text":"While not completely necessary, wrapping ampules in foil helps organize large numbers of ampules during oxidation. In the event of an ampule leak or breakage, wrapping ampules can maintain the integrity and readability of ampule labels. If you are unsure whether a particular ampule has a strong seal, you may want to wrap that ampule individually. If analyzing replicates, you may choose to wrap replicate ampules together.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Oxidation of SPE-DOC with nitric acid
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ccq13","text":"Place pouches together in a glass beaker or other glass container and place in a temperature controlled oven.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a96lt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8d5m1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ilhg","text":"This step is optional, but it makes it easier to transfer ampules in and out of the oven safely and efficiently. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fkv86","text":"At this point, the sealed glass ampules contain sample benzenepolycarboxylic acids (BPCAs) and other SPE-DOC oxidation products dissolved in the concentrated nitric acid. In this step, the concentrated nitric acid is removed through evaporation under a stream of inert gas so the BPCAs can be prepared for separation and quantification by high performance liquid chromatography steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cqqpa","text":"Transfer the target volume of mobile phase A to the ampule containing the dry BPCA-containing residue using a volumetric pipette. steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cpd4n","text":"Rinse the entire interior surface of the ampule with the volume of mobile phase A added.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"epiqt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cujad","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ancq6","text":"This step usually requires a combination of gentle shaking, rolling, and tilting of the ampule for a minute or two to effectively re-dissolve the BPCAs in the mobile phase A added. It is important to make sure that the mobile phase rinses every part of the interior surface of the ampule to ensure quantitative detection and analysis of BPCAs in a given sample. Whatever method you use to re-dissolve the BPCAs, keep your approach consistent among different samples. Take care not to spill any mobile phase during this step.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Transfer of BPCAs from ampules to HPLC vials
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c7473","text":"Using a clean glass or plastic pipette, transfer the mobile phase in the ampule, which now contains re-dissolved BPCAs, from the ampule to the insert in the corresponding HPLC vial.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ao8pr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a26sn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uhao","text":"When transferring the sample, place the pipette tip at the bottom of the vial insert and slowly deposit the sample to avoid bubble formation at the bottom of the insert.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1q23u","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d0u8q","text":"Note that there may still be some mobile phase residue left in the ampule after transfer to the HPLC vial. This will not affect the accurate calculation of DBC concentrations because the concentration of BPCAs in the vial insert is representative of all BPCAs derived from the sample dissolved in the target volume of mobile phase A originally added to the ampule.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2q3t2","text":"The flame sealing of ampules requires a beaker of water, long metal forceps, safety glasses, and a blow torch that is sufficiently hot enough to melt borosilicate glass.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"827s2","text":"Turn on the torch. Hold ampule at a 45 degree angle. steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"nrrl","text":"Hold the upper neck area of the ampule in the flame and slowly rotate until the glass begins to soften.
