After removing the top part of the ampule, hold the sealed portion in the flame for an extra second or so to ensure a good seal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bubm1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"46dg7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di50","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fl8v3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"video","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"12339A406F1911ECA6296F943B28F2BB","height":0,"id":197355,"is_video":true,"legend":"","mime":"video/mp4","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"seal.mp4","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gaznbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gazmbj36p.mp4","width":0}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vqun","text":"Do not twist the glass too quickly, or before the glass is sufficiently malleable, as this may result in a poor seal. Rotate the bottom of the ampule with your hand and gently open and close the forceps to obtain the best seal.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Nitric acid addition and sealing ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"624tl","text":"Place the top piece of the ampule (pulled off using forceps) into the beaker of water to cool. Carefully place sealed ampule into a tray using the forceps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2sml","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c1afs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":31,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"a7nko","text":"Freshly sealed ampules are HOT - Move them using the forceps until they are cool to the touch.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2ek2g","text":"Remove ampules from freezer and place in a rack. Gently flick the top of each ampule to dislodge any nitric acid solution that may be trapped near the sealed ampule tip and let the solution drip down to the bottom of the ampule. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ed0o4","text":"Pipette 40 μL of concentrated nitric acid into the tops of each ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cjvsg","text":"Roll and swirl the ampule top to rinse the entire inner surface area and to collect any BPCA-residue in the top of the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ep057","text":"Using a fresh pipette tip, transfer the nitric acid rinsing from the ampule top to the corresponding bottom. Repeat this step for all samples, changing pipette tips between each sample to prevent cross contamination.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5kuec","text":"Gently push opened ampule into the sand to just below the shoulder of the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fd563","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhl1c","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5u09i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f7dpu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"BC7775A075A211ECBAA635D6A49661B6","height":389,"id":209597,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uha0","text":"Image of ampules positioned in a sand bath.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"IMG_8006j.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnx9bj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnx7bj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnx8bj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnx6bj36p.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"69bam","text":"Using the setup shown here, we can fit 5 ampules per sand bath. The exact configuration may vary depending upon how you build your drying apparatus.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"97hp2","text":"Remove steel needle covers and clean each needle with a Kimwipe soaked in methanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7at3c","text":"Insert needle into the headspace of the ampule so the tip of the needle is hovering just above the surface of the nitric acid in the ampule.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amstt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5de5h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":69,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"2ck8t","text":"Take care when inserting and removing needles to and from the ampules - There is a risk getting sand in your samples. If you accidentally introduce sand to the ampules, take notes on which samples were affected and check BPCA analyses later for possible signs of contamination. Since the BPCAs are chromatographically separated, contamination from sand is unlikely to interfere with DBC quantification results.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3e17s","text":"SLOWLY increase gas flow. The nitric acid solution in each ampule should shimmer slightly, not sputter aggressively. You may observe dark orange-to-light colored fumes emitting from the ampules.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4krff","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d6a97","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fog84","text":"To optimize evaporation, you may adjust gas flow and/or needle height periodically during dry down as the liquid level decreases. This step requires a watchful eye and some degree of “babysitting” to ensure efficient evaporation. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Solid Phase Extraction: Elution of SPE-DOC with methanol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cbmn9","text":"At this point, you may continue directly to the next step or store eluate in the freezer until you are ready to continue. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"de31i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3kcnc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":76,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8ceoh","text":"Note that each SPE cartridge may be used up to three times before disposal. After DOM elution, SPE cartridges can be rinsed with analytical grade acetone (3 headspace volumes) and set aside to air dry. Once dry, the SPE cartridges can be reconditioned (see steps 1 though 6) and reused for DOM extraction. We recommend that each SPE cartridge is reused with a similar sample type so as to avoid potential cross contamination. For example, do not use an SPE cartridge to first extract a high DOC swamp water sample, then extract a low DOC open ocean sample. It is best when SPE cartridges are reused within the same sample set or for samples collected at the same field site.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4t4uc","text":"The HPLC separation method described here was first presented by Wagner et al. (2017) for online compound-specific stable carbon isotopic analysis. In this protocol, we use the same chromatographic parameters, but with UV detection, for the efficient quantification of DBC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9or0c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fb3n","text":"HPLC system and user-related assumptions - For the purposes of this protocol, we assume that the user will have access to an HPLC system that is equipped with an autosampler, binary or quaternary pump (for gradient separation), a UV or photo diode array detector, and software to assemble methods and sequences and for instrumental operation. We also assume that the user has basic knowledge of how to operate an HPLC system and/or has access to someone who can assist them with basic operation of an HPLC system. For example, we do not go into detail about how to flush solvent lines or properly hook up and equilibrate an HPLC column. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8rrp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"960ds","text":"HPLC instrument settings for the chromatographic separation of BPCAs are as follows: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":85}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fok66","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3938s","text":"Column: Agilent Poroshell 120 phenyl-hexyl column (4.6 x 150 mm, 2.7 μm) with corresponding guard column (4.6 x 5 mm, 2.7 μm)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15tcp","text":"Mobile phase A: Phosphoric acid (0.6 M; pH 1)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3e0ft","text":"Mobile phase B: Sodium phosphate buffer (20 mM; pH 6)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4qqs","text":"Flow rate: 500 μL min-1","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":21,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5usi7","text":"Column temperature: 25°C (if available)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11pm2","text":"Autosampler temperature: 25°C (if available)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4hi7l","text":"Injection volume: 25 μL","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v6f6","text":"Peak detection: 240 nm","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnkt2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8j1jb","text":"Set up the HPLC according to the parameters listed above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dn2rn","text":"Place blank, BPCA standard, and sample vials into the appropriate autosampler positions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtr7f","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8uptj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1347n","text":"If you are analyzing samples that were previously stored in the freezer, visually check to make sure bubbles have not formed in the bottom of the vial inserts. If you observe bubbles or are unsure, you can shake the vial in a downward flicking motion to ensure the liquid in the vial settles in the bottom of the insert. You may also use a pipette to mix and deposit your sample, but this may introduce extraneous material to the vial.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fdqmg","text":"At this point, the HPLC system should be set up for BPCA analysis and the column is properly equilibrated with mobile phase (70% A and 30% B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b58ab","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl6o","text":"Run the HPLC sequence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bg1eh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ccrm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jopj","text":"Note that the mobile phase B reservoir will empty faster than the mobile phase A reservoir. Depending upon the length of the sequence, it could take several days to analyze a full sample set. We suggest checking on the instrument at least daily to refill mobile phase reservoirs and to check for leaks or other observable issues with separation. We also suggest checking whether the BPCA standards ran well before continuing to analyze the rest of the dataset.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Chromatographic separation of individual BPCAs
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5opfb","text":"Examine the chromatogram for each BPCA standard run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4364o","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5o3e0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3oelq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"EC5459407B2511EC972B97273AB33C76","height":162,"id":209601,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7jb74","text":"Chromatogram of a standard mixture","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Standard Run.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnydbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnybbj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnycbj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnyabj36p.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"15s0n","text":"In each BPCA standard chromatogram, you should observe baseline separation of B6CA at a retention time of ~5 minutes and baseline separation of B5CA at a retention time of ~12 minutes. The 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid standard is baseline separated at a retention time of ~18 minutes and the benzenetricarboxylic acids usually co-elute around a retention time of ~24 minutes.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"v5j2","text":"Examine the chromatogram for each sample run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3lfo6","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"45k04","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"57dac","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"58CA01107B2611EC972B97273AB33C76","height":188,"id":209613,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7c5c0","text":"Chromatogram of dissolved organic matter sample","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Sample Run.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnyrbj36p.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnypbj36p.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnyqbj36p.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gnynbj36p.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f2bt3","text":"Sample oxidation products contain target BPCAs in addition to numerous other organic components. Compounds B6CA and B5CA are usually baseline-separated and are identified by comparison of sample peak retention times with that of BPCA standard runs. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"186vd","text":"Open stopcock to allow sample water to flow through it by gravity. Allow 5 to 10 mL of sample to flow out to waste, then close the stopcock.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kdfg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f8dtf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"29mrg","text":"This step begins flow, but also rinses the interior of the Teflon tube with sample before connection to the conditioned SPE cartridge.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6b05r","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3kke7","text":"If sample water does not begin flowing from gravity alone, you may use a syringe to gently apply vacuum to the stopcock end of the Teflon tube to initiate flow.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Sample Oxidation: Transfer of SPE-DOC eluate to ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3dhc9","text":"Using a mechanical pipette, fitted with a glass Pasteur pipette tip, quantitatively transfer the calculated volume of methanol eluate (\"V MeOH to dry\" in spreadsheet) to the corresponding ampule. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9o3gt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87k6i","text":"Triple-rinse the glass pipette tip with fresh methanol before use and between each sample to prevent cross contamination. Dispose of each rinsing to the appropriate solvent waste container.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ei4j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cdav8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":24,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"30b22","text":"Mechanical pipette setup - Here, we use a small piece of silicone tubing to fit the glass Pasteur pipette tip to the mechanical pipette. Using the glass pipette prevents possible contamination of organic material from plastic pipette tips.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7sul7","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":31,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"fad83","text":"Quantitative transfer technique - When transferring the methanol eluate, insert tip of Pasteur pipette into methanol eluate and slowly pump up and down 3 to 5 times until the headspace in the Pasteur pipette is equilibrated and bubbles are no longer emitted from the pipette tip. After equilibrating, draw in the target amount of methanol eluate and transfer to the ampule. When transferring, place the pipette tip all the way down the neck of the ampule and try to make sure the eluate is deposited directly to the bottom of the ampule. Gently pump the pipette 3 to 5 times to ensure the total volume of methanol eluate is expelled into the ampule.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e9d04","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":56,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ec2cb","text":"What if the \"V MeOH to dry\" volume is greater than 2 mL? Each ampule can contain up to 2 mL of methanol eluate. If the volume of eluate that needs to be dried down exceeds 2 mL, then we suggest transferring and drying the eluate in aliquots of 2 mL or less (see next step). Do not overfill the ampules, as this will cause the SPE-DOC to dry on the neck of the ampule and may interfere with analysis later.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: HPLC Analysis of BPCAs: Evaporation of nitric acid from ampules
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"64gsf","text":"After nitric acid has completely evaporated, turn off gas flow and remove needles from ampules and remove ampules from the sand bath. Gently wipe down the exterior of each ampule to remove excess sand.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5b783","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4s8hq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":48,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"basa2","text":"Signs that nitric acid is completely evaporated - If the steel needle and area around the opening of the ampule are completely dry, then it is likely that all nitric acid has been evaporated. If you remove the ampule and notice that some nitric acid remains, simply replace the ampule in the sand bath and continue drying. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7481s","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":37,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9n0b5","text":"Appearance of BPCA-containing residue - The dry BPCA-containing residue left in the ampule is typically clear, white, or light yellow in color. The residue may not always be readily apparent to the naked eye.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"avt80","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":41,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bbv1n","text":"Turn off gas flow BEFORE removing needles - If you remove needles while gas is still flowing, then sand will blow all over the place.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
